suggestedSubTickets.description:
**Auto-generated sub-ticket from COD-21**

Address complexity issues in src/experimental/DeveloperMoodTracker.js (score: 17)

**Scope:**
Files to modify:
- src/experimental/DeveloperMoodTracker.js

**Complexity:** high
**Priority:** medium

**Parent Ticket:** COD-21 - final_tests

ai.title: feat(experimental): Add DeveloperMoodTracker to monitor developer mood
ai.body:
This PR introduces an experimental feature called `DeveloperMoodTracker`. This class analyzes commit messages and code changes to gauge developer mood and provide insights into team productivity.

**Functionality:**

* **Mood Analysis:** Analyzes commit messages for keywords (e.g., 'fix', 'feat', 'refactor') and code changes (lines and files changed) to assign a mood emoji (😴, 😤, 🤔, 😊, 🚀, 🔥).
* **Mood History:** Maintains a history of moods with timestamps and commit contexts for trend analysis.
* **Mood Trend:** Calculates the dominant mood over the last 5 commits.
* **Mood Report:** Generates a summary report for team standups, including current mood trend, total commits, recent activity, and a productivity tip.

**How it works:**

The `analyzeMood` function assesses sentiment from the commit message and the number of lines/files changed.  This score is then used to assign a mood emoji and stored in the mood history. The `getMoodTrend` function analyzes the recent mood history to identify the current mood. The `generateMoodReport` function provides a neatly formatted summary of this data.

**Example Usage:**

javascript
const tracker = new DeveloperMoodTracker();
const mood = tracker.analyzeMood('Fix: Resolved critical bug', 150, 3);
console.log(mood); // Might output 😤
console.log(tracker.generateMoodReport());


This feature is experimental and can be further improved with more sophisticated sentiment analysis and potentially integration with other metrics.
ai.summary: Adds an experimental feature to track developer mood based on commit messages and code changes, providing insights into team productivity and well-being.

architectureDiagrams.title: Project Architecture
architectureDiagrams.mermaid:
graph TB
    subgraph "Frontend Layer"
        UI[User Interface]
        COMP[Components]
    end

    subgraph "Business Logic Layer"
        SERV[Services]
        WORK[Workflows]
    end

    subgraph "Data Layer"
        API[API Clients]
        CACHE[Cache]
    end

    subgraph "External Services"
        GH[GitHub API]
        LIN[Linear API]
        AI[AI Services]
    end

    UI --> COMP
    COMP --> SERV
    SERV --> WORK
    WORK --> API
    API --> GH
    API --> LIN
    API --> AI
    SERV --> CACHE

    classDef frontend fill:#e3f2fd,stroke:#1976d2
    classDef business fill:#f3e5f5,stroke:#7b1fa2
    classDef data fill:#e8f5e8,stroke:#388e3c
    classDef external fill:#fff3e0,stroke:#f57c00
    class UI,COMP frontend
    class SERV,WORK business
    class API,CACHE data
    class GH,LIN,AI external

pr.title: feat(experimental): Add DeveloperMoodTracker to monitor developer mood
pr.body:
This PR introduces an experimental feature called `DeveloperMoodTracker`. This class analyzes commit messages and code changes to gauge developer mood and provide insights into team productivity.

**Functionality:**

* **Mood Analysis:** Analyzes commit messages for keywords (e.g., 'fix', 'feat', 'refactor') and code changes (lines and files changed) to assign a mood emoji (😴, 😤, 🤔, 😊, 🚀, 🔥).
* **Mood History:** Maintains a history of moods with timestamps and commit contexts for trend analysis.
* **Mood Trend:** Calculates the dominant mood over the last 5 commits.
* **Mood Report:** Generates a summary report for team standups, including current mood trend, total commits, recent activity, and a productivity tip.

**How it works:**

The `analyzeMood` function assesses sentiment from the commit message and the number of lines/files changed.  This score is then used to assign a mood emoji and stored in the mood history. The `getMoodTrend` function analyzes the recent mood history to identify the current mood. The `generateMoodReport` function provides a neatly formatted summary of this data.

**Example Usage:**

javascript
const tracker = new DeveloperMoodTracker();
const mood = tracker.analyzeMood('Fix: Resolved critical bug', 150, 3);
console.log(mood); // Might output 😤
console.log(tracker.generateMoodReport());


This feature is experimental and can be further improved with more sophisticated sentiment analysis and potentially integration with other metrics.
